diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's most common in infants and young children.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious infectious disease caused by the measles virus. Symptoms include fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a rash.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can develop in people who have strep throat. It's characterized by a bright red rash on the body, fever, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening skin disorder that causes the skin to peel off in sheets. It's usually caused by a reaction to drugs.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
diagnoses.description: A drug reaction that can cause a rash, fever, inflammation of internal organs, lymphadenopathy, and eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus infection
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by adenovirus. Symptoms may include sore throat, pneumonia, diarrhea, and pink eye.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection best known by its distinctive red rash. It's also known as German measles.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth disease)
diagnoses.description: A mild viral infection that most commonly affects children. Symptoms include a low-grade fever, fatigue, and a slap-cheek rash.

diagnoses.name: Hand, foot, and mouth disease
diagnoses.description: A mild, contagious viral infection common in young children, characterized by sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet.

diagnoses: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

Psychotic disorder due to a general medical condition
Hepatitis B or C with associated cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including skin, joints, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain. It can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including dyspigmentation, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. The condition may present with dyspigmentation, and systemic involvement can lead to pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from a deficiency of vitamin C, which is necessary for the synthesis of collagen in humans. Symptoms can include follicular hyperkeratosis, and in severe cases, systemic involvement may lead to pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin A deficiency
diagnoses.description: A deficiency in vitamin A can lead to follicular hyperkeratosis and has been associated with an impaired immune response, although more indirectly linked to symptoms like pericardial or pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include dry skin (follicular hyperkeratosis) and in advanced cases, myxedema coma, which can feature pleural and pericardial effusions, and altered mental status, including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Kwashiorkor
diagnoses.description: A form of severe malnutrition characterized by protein deficiency, which can cause dermatologic abnormalities including dyspigmentation and follicular hyperkeratosis, and can lead to anasarca, potentially contributing to pleural and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In skin, it can cause dyspigmentation and plaques. Sarcoidosis can also cause pleural effusion and pericardial effusion, with systemic involvement potentially leading to cognitive symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system. It can lead to skin changes (including dyspigmentation), follicular hyperkeratosis, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and delirium, depending on the extent and location of disease spread.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features commonly seen in lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis, including pleural and pericardial effusion, and skin changes like dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac temponade
diagnoses.description: A critical condition in which fluid accumulates in the pericardium (the sac in which the heart is enclosed), exerting pressure on the heart. It may cause pericardial effusion and can lead to systemic symptoms such as altered mental status or delirium if severe enough.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Parvovirus B19, Coxsackievirus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune encephalitis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Malaria)
Autoimmune vasculitis (such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika virus)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (in the context of concurrent medical illness)
Schizophrenia (for isolated psychosis with no clear inflammatory cause)
Vitamin A deficiency (for follicular hyperkeratosis, though rare in association with the other symptoms)
Acute kidney injury (AKI) secondary to nephrotoxic drugs or infections
Viral infection (e.g., dengue fever, Ebola, COVID-19)
Allergic reaction leading to Kounis syndrome
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis)
Autoimmune disorders (such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis)
Eating disorder (anorexia nervosa or bulimia nervosa)
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Upper respiratory tract infection
diagnoses.description: A common contagious infection of the structures of the upper respiratory tract, which includes the sinuses, nasal passages, pharynx, and larynx.

diagnoses.name: Allergic rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms, which can lead to sinusitis and other complications.

diagnoses.name: Acute otitis media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the air-filled space behind the eardrum (the middle ear). It's common in children and can lead to irritability and potential complications if untreated.

diagnoses.name: Acute bronchitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the main airways of the lungs (bronchi), causing them to become irritated and inflamed.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which a person's airways become inflamed, narrow and swell, and produce extra mucus, which makes it difficult to breathe.

diagnoses.name: Atopic dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. It often occurs alongside other allergic conditions like allergic rhinitis.

diagnoses.name: Viral upper respiratory infection
diagnoses.description: A viral infection affecting the nose, throat, and airways, leading to symptoms similar to a cold but can also include fever and malaise.

diagnoses.name: Chronic sinusitis
diagnoses.description: A common condition in which the cavities around nasal passages (sinuses) become inflamed and swollen for at least 12 weeks, despite treatment attempts.

diagnoses.name: Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes the skin to become itchy, reddened, cracked, and dry.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in or improper function of a protein called C1 inhibitor, leading to recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema).

diagnoses: Depression (as a comorbid condition impacting or resulting from chronic illness)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

reasoning: Hypoglycemia is a common manifestation, especially in patients undergoing treatment. Though not directly related, diabetes management during pregnancy is crucial to prevent complications.
Hypothyroidism can contribute to menstrual irregularities, infertility, and miscarriage. Hypothyroidism can also lead to anemia.
Conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can lead to miscarriage and anemia, and can have a role in vulvodynia.
PCOS can lead to menstrual irregularities and is a risk factor for miscarriage. It is also associated with insulin resistance, which can lead to hypoglycemia.
This is a direct cause of anemia and can result from heavy menstrual periods or pregnancy loss.
Diseases like Crohn's disease can lead to anemia and potentially affect pregnancy outcome. While not directly linked, systemic inflammation might play a role in vulvodynia.
Chronic infections can lead to anemia and have been implicated in miscarriages. Some vaginal infections can contribute to vulvodynia.
This can cause painful conditions such as vulvodynia and is a known risk factor for miscarriage. It may also indirectly contribute to anemia via menstrual irregularities.
Uterine fibroids can lead to heavy menstrual bleeding, contributing to anemia and miscarriage.

Stress can exacerbate conditions like vulvodynia and possibly lead to reproductive issues. Though not a direct cause of the listed medical conditions, stress management is an important aspect of comprehensive care.

diagnoses.name: Oral Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory condition of the mucous membranes inside the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels throughout your body, including the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Known for causing hypermobility and poor healing.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that involves blistering and erosion of the skin and mucous membranes, including in the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that occurs in the mouth, it can start as leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies (B12, Zinc, Folate)
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in certain vitamins can cause mouth ulcers and other oral symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the mouth and eyes.

diagnoses.name: Herpes Simplex Virus
diagnoses.description: A virus that can cause recurrent ulcers and blisters in the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Candidiasis
diagnoses.description: A fungal infection that can cause white patches in the mouth similar to leukoplakia, alongside oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Oral Thrush
diagnoses.description: An overgrowth of Candida yeast in the mouth, leading to white lesions, pain, and sometimes difficulty swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. The tumors are usually noncancerous (benign), but sometimes can become cancerous (malignant). Symptoms include skin changes and bone deformities. It can also cause developmental issues and multiple neurological complications, including those affecting hearing.

diagnoses.name: Von Hippel-Lindau disease
diagnoses.description: This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the formation of tumors and fluid-filled sacs (cysts) in many different parts of the body. Symptoms include problems with balance and coordination, dizziness (vertigo), and high blood pressure. Angiomas can also appear in the retina of the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Sturge-Weber syndrome
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by a distinctive port-wine stain on the face, neurological abnormalities, and vascular eye abnormalities. Angiomata are commonly associated with this syndrome and can affect various organs.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive heart disease
diagnoses.description: A complication of high blood pressure that affects the heart's function and structure. Symptoms can include chest pain, difficulty breathing, and in later stages, heart failure.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor that develops on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain. It can cause hearing loss, ringing in the ear (tinnitus), and loss of balance.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular dysplasia
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes abnormal growth or development of cells in the walls of blood vessels, which can lead to a variety of complications, including high blood pressure, headaches, and ringing in the ears.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that can affect the brain and spinal cord. It can cause symptoms such as numbness, weakness, balance issues, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Laryngitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the larynx, often causing a temporary voice loss or hoarseness. While it is typically a symptom, rather than a disease, it can sometimes be indicative of underlying conditions when presented with a combination of other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect the heart muscle. Symptoms can include shortness of breath, feeling tired, swelling of the legs, and chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Tuberous sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous noncancerous (benign) tumors in many parts of the body, including the brain, kidneys, heart, lungs, and skin. Tumors in the brain can lead to seizures, developmental delays, and problems with mental function.

diagnoses: Iron Overload Disorders, such as Hemochromatosis

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Connective tissue diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
reasoning: Depression is a common psychiatric manifestation.
Striae (purple or pink stretch marks) can appear due to skin fragility.
Oral leukoplakia might appear due to immune suppression.
Oral pain could be linked to various oral health issues stemming from hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
reasoning: Can cause oral pain due to recurrent aphthous ulcers.
Migratory pruritus might relate to its skin manifestations like erythema nodosum.
Depression might occur due to the chronic nature of the disease and its impact on quality of life.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
reasoning: Oral pain due to atrophic glossitis.
Depression could be a secondary effect due to overall health deterioration.
Leukoplakia, though not directly linked, might appear due to general mucosal vulnerability.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
reasoning: Depression is a common comorbidity due to the chronic nature of the disease.
Striae due to skin changes associated with hormonal imbalances.
Oral pain due to uremic stomatitis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
reasoning: Oral leukoplakia is a common manifestation.
Depression due to psychological impact and CNS involvement.
Chronic pruritus as a result of immune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
reasoning: Depression is common due to hormonal imbalance and psychological impact.
Striae due to rapid weight changes or cortisol levels.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
reasoning: Oral pain due to erosive oral lichen planus.
Migratory pruritus due to its primary symptom of pruritic, purple, polygonal papules.
Leukoplakia as it can manifest as white patches in the oral region.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
reasoning: Oral lesions including oral pain and leukoplakia-like appearances in secondary stage.
Depression due to neurological involvement in tertiary stage.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
reasoning: Depression due to the impact of chronic cortisol deficiency.
Oral pain can be associated with mucosal changes.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
reasoning: Depression is a common symptom due to the overall metabolic slowdown.
Striae as a less common symptom due to skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. The excess iron is stored in various organs, particularly the liver. Hyperferritinemia is a common finding in hemochromatosis.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). The swelling can occur in various parts of the body, including the skin, intestines, and airways.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus can lead to hyperferritinemia, poor healing, and potentially pruritic skin conditions.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that can cause hyperferritinemia and general symptoms like poor healing due to overall impact on immune function. Skin involvement may lead to pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. It can affect healing processes and, in complicated cases, lead to pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting the liver, such as cirrhosis or hepatitis C, can result in hyperferritinemia and poor healing. Liver diseases can also cause pruritus due to bile acid accumulation in the skin.

diagnoses.name: Iron Overload Syndromes
diagnoses.description: Conditions, other than hemochromatosis, that may lead to the accumulation of iron in the body tissues, causing similar symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It can affect the healing process and lead to various skin manifestations, including pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Impaired kidney function can lead to a multitude of systemic symptoms, including those related to skin health and wound healing.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis characterized by fever, rash, and joint pain. High levels of ferritin are a hallmark of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders where part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly, leading to increased infections, skin conditions like eczema, and potentially impacting growth and development.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
diagnoses.description: Virus that attacks the immune system, leading to a progressive decrease in the number of T cells, increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, and could potentially impact growth and development in youths.

diagnoses.name: DiGeorge Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder caused by a defect in chromosome 22, leading to poor development of several bodily systems, including immune deficiency, delayed puberty, and other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Hypogammaglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lower than normal level of immunoglobulins in the blood, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, possibly associated with other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the disturbed development of functional T cells and B cells caused by numerous genetic mutations, leading to severe infections, eczema, and other immune-related symptoms often from infancy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that affects the immune system, leading to the body’s inability to effectively combat certain bacterial and fungal infections.

diagnoses.name: Myelodysplastic Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells, leading to issues like leukopenia and increased infection risk due to the mediating impact on the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency disorder characterized by low levels of serum immunoglobulins (antibodies) leading to an increased susceptibility to infections, potential for autoimmune disease, and can impact body development.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a low or absent level of a blood protein known as immunoglobulin A (IgA), which is crucial in the immune function of mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: GATA2 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that can lead to problems with the immune system, blood system, and an increased risk of certain infections and cancers. It can include symptoms such as leukopenia and susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: PCOS can cause alopecia due to hormonal imbalance. While not directly associated with all the listed symptoms, the hormonal imbalances can lead to a variety of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Anxiety can manifest in physical symptoms such as obsessive-compulsive behavior. It's less directly connected to the other symptoms but can exacerbate or contribute to them.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reasoning: COPD is characterized by wheezing among other symptoms. While less directly related to the other symptoms, it is important to consider in differential diagnoses.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Atopic dermatitis can sometimes result in skin manifestations such as alopecia and can be associated with other allergic symptoms such as wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Vaginosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Bacterial vaginosis presents primarily with vaginitis. It's less directly related to the other symptoms but should be ruled out in the differential diagnosis process.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.reasoning: This genetic disorder can explain the presence of multiple angiomata. Its direct relationship with the other symptoms might be less apparent but could be part of a broader systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting the immune system, SCID could theoretically contribute to recurrent vaginitic infections due to the immune system's inability to properly combat pathogens.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.reasoning: Asthma can explain wheezing and may be exacerbated by or coexist with other allergic conditions that could indirectly relate to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
diagnoses.reasoning: OCD can account for the obsessive-compulsive behavior and, in severe cases, might indirectly affect the patient's physical health in a variety of ways, including neglect of chronic conditions.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Contact dermatitis can sometimes cause alopecia if the scalp or adjacent areas are affected. It's more peripherally related to the other symptoms but could be a part of the patient's symptomatology.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure can cause damage to blood vessels, potentially leading to epistaxis, and has been associated with tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses can lead to post-nasal drip, tinnitus due to blocked Eustachian tubes, and sometimes ulcers in nasal passages.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation of the blood vessels, which can lead to nasal ulcers, epistaxis, and potentially affect hearing.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, potentially leading to dry eyes (difficulty focusing vision), nasal dryness and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, can lead to mouth and genital ulcers, and may potentially cause epistaxis and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing symptoms like post-nasal drip, and can contribute to epistaxis and sinus pressure potentially affecting vision and causing tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Nasal Polyps
diagnoses.description: Soft, painless, noncancerous growths on the lining of your nasal passages or sinuses can lead to post-nasal drip, difficulty breathing, and sometimes ulcers or epistaxis if they cause irritation or bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a range of symptoms depending on which organs or tissues are affected, potentially leading to epistaxis, ulcers, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: While not directly causing the listed symptoms, poorly controlled diabetes can lead to complications that affect many parts of the body, including vision issues and susceptibility to infections that could indirectly contribute to the symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A lack of zinc can lead to symptoms like impaired wound healing (potentially relevant for ulcers), altered vision, and has been speculated to contribute to tinnitus.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Allergic reaction to food or medication
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Bacterial Infections (e.g., Salmonella, E. coli, Campylobacter)
Neurogenic shock (due to spinal cord injury)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Gastrointestinal Disorders (that can cause severe vomiting leading to syncope)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with skin involvement
Diabetic ketoacidosis (if the patient has diabetes)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and other problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines that involve visual disturbances (such as scotoma) and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted, leading to brain tissue damage.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause various neurological symptoms depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the peripheral nerves.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A lack of vitamin B12 that can lead to neurological and hematological disorders.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks.

diagnoses.name: Arnold-Chiari Malformation
diagnoses.description: A condition in which brain tissue extends into the spinal canal, leading to various symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection of the brain or spinal cord that can occur in people who have had syphilis for many years.

diagnoses: Chronic kidney disease (secondary to conditions like diabetes mellitus)
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Epilepsy (secondary to cerebral vasculitis or antiphospholipid syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Glomerulonephritis with systemic disease (e.g., lupus nephritis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
